title-group.article-title: The Finite Element Method with Nonuniform Mesh Sizes for Unbounded Domains

abstract.p: The finite element method with nonuniform mesh sizes is employed to approximately solve elliptic boundary value problems in unbounded domains. Consider the following model problem: $$-\Delta u = f\quad\text{in}\quad\Omega^C, \quad u = g\quad\text{on}\quad\partial\Omega, \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial r} + \frac{1}{r} u = o\bigg(\frac{1}{r}\bigg)\quad\text{as}\quad r = |x| \rightarrow \infty,$$ where $\Omega^C$ is the complement in $R^3$ (three-dimensional Euclidean space) of a bounded set $\Omega$ with smooth boundary $\partial\Omega$, $f$ and $g$ are smooth functions, and $f$ has bounded support. This problem is approximately solved by introducing an artificial boundary $\Gamma_R$ near infinity, e.g. a sphere of sufficiently large radius $R$. The intersection of this sphere with $\Omega^C$ is denoted by $\Omega^C_R$ and the given problem is replaced by $$-\Delta u_R = f\quad\text{in}\quad\Omega^C_R, \quad u_R = g\quad\text{on}\quad\partial\Omega, \quad \frac{\partial u_R}{\partial r} + \frac{1}{r} u_R = 0\quad\text{on}\quad\Gamma_R.$$ This problem is then solved approximately by the finite element method, resulting in an approximate solution $u^h_R$ for each $h > 0$. In order to obtain a reasonably small error for $u - u^h_R = (u - u_R) + (u_R - u^h_R)$, it is necessary to make $R$ large. This necessitates the solution of a large number of linear equations, so that this method is often not very good when a uniform mesh size $h$ is employed. It is shown that a nonuniform mesh may be introduced in such a way that optimal error estimates hold and the number of equations is bounded by $Ch^{-3}$ with $C$ independent of $h$ and $R$.
